comments.commentBody: they are caught and the truth is known to all except the Russian populace who really don't care about the truth only their return to the world stage as a dominate player...

We can look at MH 17 and J. Foley. Boots on the ground are not going to resolve the problems in Ukraine. This is the apparent will of President Obama. How far is Putin going to go? That is the subject of discussion about Ukraine. Will that Russian soldier be decapitated? I doubt it but at what price is this little discussion focused on? Even if the filters are on the items do not reach our enemies. This is a local problem that needs to be spoken of and about. I don't want to have nightmares because apparently my world is coming to an end as may the case be in Ukraine. Iraq and Syria are child's play as is perhaps truly the case there. In Iraq and Syria the people there are truly children because they choose war and a decapitated enemy over peace. Can we discuss Ukraine with all of the distraction that is happening with Islamic State? There are people that would have the world to genuinely end during the night such that they would not know the final price that these games are leading towards. Life is not to be discussed in this way. Or is it?

Let us hope that Ukraine can hold the line against RF in the Donbass region of Ukraine There are no other possibilities if the sanctions are not effective against RF. Feeling the effects are not the same as not having the resources to deal with them.

to KJ

To prove me wrong all what one needs is just a single image or a link to it that would show all 10 or 12 (whatever the final number is) of Russian solders alive and unharmed. That is it -- not personal insults, not request to assume Kiev innocent while knowing that there are hundreds civilians dead due to Kiev's military activity in the area.
Given the behavior of the Russian troops, I mean Ukranian separatists, maybe we should also be launching airstrikes against them as well as ISIS.

The visual evidence of Russian T-72 tanks (only Russia has these models) in Donetsk as well the captured Russian soldiers in pretend uniforms provide proof this is a Russian invasion, not merely a bunch of rebels being stage managed by Russian GRU and FSB. Strelkov was no "rebel" he's a member of Russia's Federal Security Service.

It's also been obvious since a few days after MH-17 was shot down that only the Russians had BUK SA-11s inside Eastern Ukraine. There was no plausible deniability - numerous photos and videos showed the BUK moving through the countryside into Ukraine and back. They placed it inside "rebel" lines at the time of the disaster. The "rebels" were not trained to operate, nor given control of a BUK, even today.

Putin is a fool. The world knows what he's doing, the only question is how long an economic war will be waged.

And we all have a right to have anything we really want, by any means necessary.
Correct?

@Maryw- That's hardly what JY said.

No, no one has a "right" to someone else's body. But this situation is not necessarily exploitative in that sense.

The surrogate who made that statement indicated that she had personal and empathetic reasons for wanting to help another person, in addition to the monetary compensation that she received. It's a more complicated situation than you're painting, and (personally) I think it rather condescending to disregard how the Thai surrogates actually feel about the process.

Please feel free to focus on the few sensational cases, the legal complications, and the unequal relationship between rich and poor women. However, don't forget the very human sentiment, as it is put by the woman in the picture, “I understand the feeling of a mother who really, really wants a child.”
Hard to see how either man is a traitor. This young man didn't attack Americans.
Considering that ISIS is obviously recruiting from the US, I'd say that YES, it is a direct threat to America!
Most disturbing, regardless of what the security "experts" may say, these expatriates could very well ind up on the streets of America.
Nothing like Edward Snowden.

Amazing how the internet has become a tool for misanthropes to unite globally for evil causes. We had better figure out a way to deal with this, because this phenomenon is here to stay. After ISIS it will just morph into something else.

If by choice you ride with outlaws, you hang with outlaws.

Ivar you sound like an intelligent person suffering idealistic notions of how this
group behaves. You should know that these people would kill you, your child and your pets if given the chance. It is you who is being utterly simplistic.

Shed no tears for someone who allies themselves with vicious killers and then dies in course of events. Spare yourself the moralistic confusion.
I hate to mention this, but US drones have also killed many innocent people.
It is only going to go further, remember when urinating on a dead sniper made the headlines. Fame in the battlefield is now a twitter post away.

So The Free Syrian Army, "our" guys, behead people too?

Is this no longer any big deal? Is there an ostensible purpose to this horror? Are all sides now terrorists?

...And these are the people who are shouting "God is great!" every ten minutes?

Madness.

I think there is a big difference between alerting the American people to espionage directed against them in secret by their government and taking up arms in support of a group that seeks to harm Americans. I can't see how you can even compare the two.

Two unwarranted conclusions, one in the article, one in several comments.

The article states, "[McCain's death] is a sign that ISIS... is willing to use Americans on the battlefield... rather than sending them back to the United States to launch attacks, as Western officials have feared."

That conclusion, though possibly correct, is not borne out by any evidence within the article. It is as likely that, if ISIS is planning to attack the U.S., using Americans on the battlefield would be a form of training and a way to vet the people being considered.

Several Commenters refer to McCain's actions as treason against the U.S. His actions simply do not fit the Constitutional definition of treason: "Treason against the United States, shall consist only in levying war against them, or in adhering to their enemies, giving them aid and comfort."

One of the grim realities of our current "wars" is that the U.S. often fights against non-state actors, whom we have not necessarily defined as the enemy, and who may one day be out of favor, and the next day in favor. (That even happens with states and their heads, as with Manuel Noriega and Saddam Hussein.) Look at how Al Qaeda is currently being juxtaposed to ISIS.

The other problem in defining a person guilty of treason is that, though we have fought five (depending on how you count them) significant wars in the past seventy years, not a single one was declared by Congress, the sole Constitutional authority for declaring war.
If we had only allowed him to rob and kill here without being punished for it, he might have stayed.

It actually means that the USA is intelligent enough to be wary of a terrorist organization that has vowed to attack us on our own soil. I only hope that their analysis on ISIS using Americans as fodder on the front lines does not mean they have not considered that ISIS may use some as fodder and save others for infiltration to perform a future attack.
With a background of legal problems, it is easy to see why they would not try to use McCain as a viable candidate to send back for a domestic attack. The success rate would be higher if they were to save that distinction for someone that did not have a checkered past.

No, you are mistaken if you equate ISIL with Islam. It's not Islam at all - at least, not in any historical sense. The young men who fight and die for ISIL are little more than soul-less monsters who have allowed themselves to be used as killing machines. They rape, torture, murder, destroy and loot. They deserve whatever horrible fate awaits them.

"Does this mean that America is so monolithic in its thinking that it is impossible to consider anything even remotely bearing an affiliation with Islam must by definition be anti-American and a direct threat."
I think you're drawing a very broad conclusion from one data point. The wide official and public rejection of ISIL and it's "Khmer Rouge-like" behavior and ideology in no way means that America and (most) Americans see the entire Islamic faith as a threat. I think it is incumbent upon religious leaders - of all faiths - to make this distinction. ISIL, despite the word Islam in its name, is NOT practicing the Islamic faith, much as drug lords in Mexico or Mafiosi in Italy who pray to various saints are not, in fact, practicing Christianity. ISIL is a gang, a cult, a terrorist group that is cleverly exploiting religion to attract recruits like McCain.

Senior administration officials and lawmakers have described ISIS as one of the most serious threats the United States has faced since the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks by Al Qaeda, and some believe the group is determined to attack in the United States.

Does this mean that America is so monolithic in its thinking that it is impossible to consider anything even remotely bearing an affiliation with Islam must by definition be anti-American and a direct threat.

Such inability to think in a nuanced way is probably also one of the symptoms of paranoia as well. Eyes lose a great deal of their irreplaceable value when all that are left are the sensors to light and dark but not to color.

The world is a multitude of colors, yet if we can only see things in black and white, how long before we become totally blind? And depending on how the dictates our reaction to things that arise for the worse, might not blindness really be better, if it spares us from making irrational and dangerous decisions?

The AARP Medicare Rx plan did the same in 2014 with Diovan. They raised the price of the generic, which  became available in 2013, to the price they had been charging for the non-generic. (In 2013, the generic was much cheaper, and the non-generic was still available in the formulary.)

I'm sitting here, my tears on overload for your losses and the love you demonstrate towards your mother as you navigate overwhelming grief in your life. May you continue to find strengh through your writing.
Do you do this by doing a drug search on Medicare.gov?

One of the things I do for my aging parents each year is match the drugs they are taking against the formularies of the Part D plans (28 this year) offered in their state.

They change every year and when Seniors simply keep a plan year to year, there may be surprises when it's time to renew a prescription, that it is no longer covered, or has jumped in price.

Since seniors take a number of drugs for various chronic conditions, monitoring for drug interactions can consume a lot of Physician time, if it is done at all.

While the Pharmacy Management companies may boost their profits with formulary changes, the overall effect, I suspect, is to incur additional medical costs.
The mnemonic for NPH is 'wacky, wobbly and wet'.

The three symptoms that you mention are the NPH 'triad'. The expression is 'wacky (cognitive issues), wobbly (gait issues; unsteadiness) and wet (continence issues)'. It's a sad thing when we have to be our own doctors and nurses. More than a few times I've had to figure things out myself.
Blessings and peace for you and your family.  We are richer that you shared your hard story.But  I wish you hadn't had to experience it in the first place,
